NYC building owners face a deadline most haven't done the math on.

Local Law 97 penalties begin in 2030. Electrical service upgrades to support heat pump retrofits take 18–24 months to permit and complete. That math closes the traditional compliance window around mid-2028 — not 2030.

Buildings that haven't started planning by mid-2026 are already running short on time for the conventional path. The alternative — routing low-voltage power distribution through existing risers without a service upgrade — was not viable under traditional wiring codes. NEC Class 4 (Article 726) changed that.

The question isn't whether to upgrade. It's whether owners have the 30 months to do it the traditional way.

For facilities and property managers: has your building started LL97 compliance planning? What's your current timeline estimate for the electrical side?
linkedin_drafts.notes: Targets NYC building owners and facilities managers; uses the LL97 deadline math as the hook

The NEC is changing article numbers for Class 4 power — and it matters for contractors bidding jobs right now.

NEC Article 726 (Class 4 / Fault Managed Power) is being renumbered to Article 722 in the 2026 code cycle. The safety model doesn't change. The wiring requirements don't change. But the article number does — and with states on 2020, 2023, and 2026 NEC simultaneously, contractors, specifiers, and inspectors may be referencing different article numbers for identical installs.

This creates a near-term permit friction window. A bid written against Article 726 may be reviewed by an AHJ who hasn't adopted the 2026 NEC yet. Or the reverse — an inspector trained on 2026 NEC may flag a permit referencing the old number.

Practical step for contractors: reference both article numbers in your permit applications and specifications until your state adopts 2026 NEC.

Has your AHJ started seeing Class 4 installs? How are they handling the code transition?
linkedin_drafts.notes: Targets electrical contractors and MEP specifiers; focused on the code transition friction

AI infrastructure is exposing a structural disconnect between IT purchasing and facilities planning.

AFCOM's latest data puts average rack density at 27 kW — up from the 8–12 kW range that most facilities infrastructure was designed for. When IT buys a GPU cluster, they're also implicitly committing facilities to a UPS and power distribution upgrade that wasn't in the capital plan.

The budget collision is predictable: IT is purchasing on an opex/product cycle, facilities is planning capital improvements on a 5–10 year schedule. By the time the power constraint shows up, the hardware is already on order.

This isn't a new problem — but the pace of AI deployment is compressing the collision timeline. Facilities managers who want to get ahead of it need to be in the IT refresh conversation before the purchase order, not after.

For data center and facilities professionals: how are you bridging IT and facilities planning on power infrastructure for AI deployments?
linkedin_drafts.notes: Targets facilities managers and data center ops; bridges IT/facilities budget conflict angle
